awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Quantum-mechanical methods for electronic excited states in complex systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Eugene DePrince of Florida State University is funded by the Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods program of the Chemistry Division to develop new theories and computer algorithms to aid in the description of the electronic structure of complex molecules and materials.  Dr. DePrince and his group are developing techniques that describe a system with many electrons using an approach (two-electron reduced-density matrix: 2-RDM) that reduces the problem to two electrons, rather than the more familiar and complicated many-electron techniques.  Because the 2-RDM approach is more compact than the many-electron wave function, these methods enable large computations on complex systems that are not possible using conventional approaches.  The theories and algorithms being developed facilitate the discovery and characterization of novel molecules and materials relevant energy conversion, catalysis, and advanced energy storage technologies. Professor DePrince is also developing Chemical Physics courses, a lecture series, and online educational content with the goal of establishing a Chemical Physics PhD track in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Florida State University.

The project aims to develop a theoretical and computational framework for the description of electronically excited states in complex systems.  Here, the term complex refers to systems that fall into one of two categories: (i) molecules whose electronic wave functions cannot be described qualitatively by a single electronic configuration (i.e. strongly correlated systems) or (ii) molecules embedded in extreme environments, such as those in the vicinity of a plasmonic nanoparticle, where intense external electric fields can significantly perturb the electron density for the molecule. For the former category, frequency- and time-domain methods are being developed to extract excited-state information from variational two-electron reduced-density matrix (2-RDM)-driven complete active space self-consistent field computations.  For the latter category, the investigator and his group are developing fully-quantum mechanical approaches that simulate plasmon-molecule interactions in the time domain. Because the plasmon is modeled in a quantum-mechanical way, such an approach captures quantum-mechanical effects, such as entanglement and coherences between plasmon excitations. Professor DePrince places the codes developed as part of this research effort in the public domain in either free or commercial electronic structure packages. Making these codes available to the public facilitates the discovery of novel materials and the advancement of the numerical methods developed throughout the project.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the project was to develop a theoretical and computational framework for the description of electronically excited states in complex molecular systems. Here, the term complex refers to systems that fall into one of two categories: (i) molecules whose electronic wave functions cannot be described qualitatively by a single electronic configuration (i.e., strongly correlated/multireference systems) or (ii) molecules embedded near plasmonic nanoparticles or within high-quality optical cavities, where perturbative descriptions of light-matter interactions could fail. For the former category, we targeted frequency- and time-domain methods to extract excited-state information from variational two-electron reduced-density-matrix (v2RDM)-driven complete active space self consistent field (CASSCF) computations. Conventional configuration interaction (CI)-based approaches to CASSCF display an exponential computational scaling with respect the the size of the active space. Variational 2-RDM-driven methods, however, scale only polynomially with the size of the active space and therefore allow for the efficient treatment of multireference electron correlation for systems with much larger active spaces than can be treated by CI-based approaches. For the latter category, we explored fully-quantum mechanical models for light-matter interaction rooted in the framework of cavity quantum electrodynamics (QED). 

Intellectual merit

The theoretical and methodological developments resulting from the project are unique. In the context of strongly-correlated electrons, this project supported the development of the first algorithm for the direct imposition of pure-state N-representability conditions in v2RDM calculations, as well as the first implementation of analytic energy gradients for v2RDM theory. We also developed a protocol for evaluating core-level spectra with v2RDM-optimized reduced density matrices using the formalism of the extended random phase approximation (ERPA). The computational machinery developed to enable ERPA calculations was then repurposed to realize novel methods for capturing dynamical electron correlation effects lacking in v2RDM-driven CASSCF calculations. In the context of strong light-matter interactions, the project resulted in the development of computational infrastructure underlying a variety of ab initio cavity QED approaches. Specifically, the project supported the development of cavity QED generalizations of several ground-state electronic structure methods, including density functional theory, coupled-cluster theory, and the v2RDM approach.

Broader Impacts : 

Computational tools for modeling electronically excited states in strongly correlated molecules and strong light-matter interactions can potentially facilitate the discovery or characterization of novel molecules and materials relevant to energy conversion, catalysis, and advanced energy storage technologies. To maximize the impact of the tools developed under this project, many of them have been released to the public in a free and open-source package called Hilbert, which is a plugin to the Psi4 electronic structure package. Beyond software-centered impacts, significant effort was undertaken to develop a series of online tutorials on C++ and Python programming for quantum chemistry applications, which are hosted on the DePrince group website. The educational impact of free, high-quality online materials can be high, as evidenced by the more than 12,000 views of our first tutorial on the Hartree-Fock self-consistent field procedure.
